Description: Fragment with impressed decorations: fragment from the shoulder and neck of a vessel in opaque dark-blue glass. There are remains of four impressed units in the form of cornflowers or rosettes represented in top view. Each is composed of an opaque white disc with a yellow centre outlined in turquoise-blue. Radiating from the circumference of the white disc are 'petals' of rectangular shape also in opaque white. In the intact vessel these impressed units probably decorated the entire exterior surface. Thick walls. Smooth tan core. The surface is slightly filmed.
Curator's comments: A duplicate but smaller fragment, almost certainly part of the same vessel, is in the Metropolitan Museum (26.7.1155, unpublished). It was in the Carnarvon Collection and is of unrecorded provenance.
Bibliographic references: Tait 1991 / Five Thousand Years of Glass (fig.32, p.33)
